moves.1. e4 Nc6 2. Nf3 e5 3. Bc4 h6 4. O-O Nf6: To play Bg7 giving black control over the long diagonal
moves.8... Bg7 9. Ba4: Pins the queen-knight and leaves the pawn at e5 without any defence
moves.11. Nxe5 Qd6 12. Nxc6: Removes the option of a queen-side castle
moves.12... bxc6 13. Nxd4 O-O: Qxd4 would have led to Bxc6ch, winning the rook
moves.14. c3 Ng4 15. Nf3: Defending the mate threat from Qxh2
moves.15... c5 16. c4 Rab8: The bishop at g7 has great control of the diagonal
moves.19... g5 20. Qa5: Attacking the pawn at a7, which could later lead to queening of one of white's queen-side pawns
moves.20... Qd6 21. Bc2: 21.Qxa7 Ra8 would lose the white queen
moves.25... Rxb2: 25. .. f6 26.d4 would win the black bishop
Does not want to exchange queens and maintain pressure on the white king
moves.33. Rb5 Bb4: The bishop-pawn pair cannot be dislodged now
moves.34... h4 35. c5 Bd7: hxg3 36.fxg3 would open the f-file for white's rook
moves.36. c6 Be6 37. d4: Threatening to block the bishop with d5
moves.39. exf6 Qxf6: Qxf3 would again be followed by Qxg5ch and subsequent mate with the help of the rook and the bishop. Note that the black bishops are too far away from the action
moves.40. Rxg5+: Initiative is completely with white now. Black can only delay the inevitable now
moves.40... Kf7 41. Bh5+ Ke7 42. Qe3+ Kd6:
42. .. Qe6 would have been followed by 43.Re5 winning the queen. Other alternatives for black were: 
i)42. .. Be6 43.d5 winning a piece for white
ii)42. .. Kd8 43.Rb5 threatening Rb8 and mate
1-0
